headline: Ghost Rails of the Holy Land
abstract: Following the dead tracks around Israel brings a forgotten Middle East back to life.
lead_paragraph: EZUZ, Israel — Once you start noticing them, ghost rails are everywhere in Israel: tracks rusting in weeds, empty limestone stations. On the Jordan River, railway ties run across a graceful bridge of black basalt that connects nothing. Under slopes of olives and pines at the banks of the Yarmouk, a tributary of the Jordan, there’s a station house used as a storeroom by fish farmers and eight abandoned rail tunnels leading to Syria.
